A Bestiary of Inspirations

Do your players know every creature they run into like the back of their hand? Are you tired of heaping completely new elements into your game every time you want to give them something different? Or are you a new GM daunted by the amount of work required to template even a single vampire, ghost or lycanthrope?

A Flock of Foes will help you use the familiar elements of the game you already know how to play. This book takes the templates and classes you understand, and uses them in original combinations to make the iconic creatures you're getting tired of fresh again for you and your players. Included are some suggestions for campaign hooks, alchemical creations, spell components, common treasure and, of course, complete stats. New rule content is kept to a minimum to facilitate the easy use of these creatures and encounters in your game.


Over 40 creatures with a "new" feel that you already know how to run, plus 20 skeletons and zombies.
Evocative illustrations bring several creatures and antagonists to life.
Suggestions for related items, power components, story hooks and other tidbits to help integrate these creatures into your game.
New templates for creating golems from other base creatures.
Complete adjusted game statistics for each creature to speed up game preparation.


A Flock of Foes is Genjitsu's first offering of new creatures built from familiar pieces, designed as an excellent resource for time-starved gamemasters.

This guidebook requires the Dungeons & Dragons Player's Handbook, 3rd Edition, published by Wizards of the Coast, Inc. This product utilizes updated material from the v.3.5 revision.

boardgame.name: Shaping the Self
boardgame.description:
Publisher description:

What Power Lies Within...

The rise of monster characters and the appearance of racial levels for common races in some games has created a whole new dimension of character development and customization. Get on top of this added layer of gaming possibility with the first multiracial player's guide and GM's race design tool. Shaping the Self includes:


Racial levels for familiar races such as dwarves, elves, halfings, and gnomes.
Templates for quick race creation, including template levels for step-by-step character transformation.
Rules for children and other 0-HD creatures.
Plenty of sample material to illustrate the principles introduced or use in your game.


Whether you want to design a race for your new campaign, improve a character's innate abilities, or simply need a village elder for your elf encounter, Shaping the Self can streamline your creation process.

boardgame.name: Wargames 3: Sentinels of Berlin
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:
The Wargames series reimagines the Iron Age of comic books as a time when the super-soldiers of the NATO Alliance faced down meta-human Soviet operatives across the Berlin Wall..

Wargames 3: Sentinels of Berlin, as with the rest of the Wargames series, is a love letter to 1980s pop culture - from movies to comics to TV shows. You'll find many a loving homage and tip of the hat to well known characters from those days.

This pdf focuses on the divided city of Cold War Berlin and the super-soldiers from both sides of the Iron Curtain who are deployed there. Like Metropolis in DC Comics or New York City in Marvel Comics, Berlin is the dramatic center of the Wargames world.

boardgame.name: Turtler
boardgame.description: This is an Icehouse board game in the style of the Frogger video game. Icehouse pieces represent cars on a road that might run over turtles that are trying to cross the road. Each player secretly programs a series of moves for their turtles, and then the moves are revealed and resolved. Hitting traffic will cause your turtle to backtrack. The first person to reach the other side of the street is the winner!

boardgame.name: Aerial Attack
Battaglia d'Artiglieria
Feindliche Flieger in Sicht!
boardgame.description:
This is a race game from 1 to 60 and was produced during the black-out period of the Blitz in Britain. Special squares on the game board resulted in different things happening during the course of the game (i.e. Dogfight in the sky, stop to watch and lose your turn, Red plane shoots down enemy, receive two tokens, black and red flyers collide, lose two turns, etc.) Players start with a number of tokens which are at different times placed in the kitty or removed from the kitty. The first player to reach #60 wins and gets 2/3rds of the kitty the second place player gets the rest.

Objective: be the first arriving at target space 60, moving by turns. Simple 'Roll & Move' game.
Translation of the title "Feindliche Flieger in Sicht!" "Enemy Planes in Sight" - see further remarks about the Klee company in the data base

boardgame.name: The Cruel Empire of Tsan Chan
boardgame.description:
From the Publisher:

Future History of the Cruel Empire of Tsan Chan
Being an account of the year Five Thousand and the creation of Empire

That cult would never die till the stars came right again, and the secret priests would take great Cthulhu from His tomb to revive His subjects and resume His rule of earth.

For the citizens of the Tsan Chan Empire, the facts of the events concerning the rise of the Great Old Ones are speculation. Life, fraught and terrifying, is best lived without pondering those momentous days hundreds or thousands of years ago. The Chanese have no reliable records of the times and the Kuen-Yuin who lived in that era provide no answers. The simple truth of their life is that to leave the boundaries of the Interdiction is to step into a world teeming with warfare, madness and the desires of black gods. Tsan Chan is the only place humans exist and it is cruel. It must be.

To the scholars of the Empire, the Kuen-Yuin, the Ophidians, matters are rather clearer, although they too suffer frustration concerning the specifics. They were not there; they were hidden in the earth, or cowering in monasteries of Leng, praying to Gods that were abandoning them.

When Cthulhu rose up again, it was the work of humans, some cult, some ancient priesthood making good on its teachings and prophecies. Throughout human history, the inevitability of this release was foretold but the consequences were debated. Some feared it meant destruction, an abattoir-era where the human race and many others were prey and nourishment. Other, were uncertain, believing the Lord of R’lyeh would teach men to laugh and revel and kill.

Those in the second camp were the most correct. Cthulhu did rise up again free from his slumber, free to make good on his antique dreams. But his ambitions were not a destroyer nor even, rightly, a conqueror. No, Cthulhu rose as an evangelist, high priest of unknowable, fabulously dangerous gods. And the shock of his presence, the power of his ministry, is today known as the Dream.

As the Old One arose, humanity was psychically damaged beyond repair. Previously, only the most ‘sensitive’ of souls could perceive the movement and desires of Cthulhu. Unfettered, free to preach, the world itself went insane. No one knows how long it took but soon, terribly soon, after Cthulhu’s release, humanity had fallen. Infected by the alien morality of the High Priest, humans became shrieking things, immoral and barbaric, completely without scruple or the faintest notion of consequence. Society and culture fell apart until humanity simply screamed the name of its new King and converted to a blind and idiot religion they could barely comprehend.

Except for a small plateau in China, where precautions had been taken.

boardgame.name: Tezelle
boardgame.description:
A tile laying, domino-style game played within the confines of a board using 2x1 oblong shaped thick cardboard tiles of a diamond design utilising seven colours.
The game box contains
4 page rules sheet in 6 languages.
a 48cm square board with 14 x 14 squares thereon onto which the tiles cover 2 adjacent squares.
a pad of score sheets.
4 x cardboard racks for players to display their tiles to them whilst concealing from other players.
a box containing 49 different tiles.

To start the game all the tiles are placed face down on the table and each player selects 8 - 10 tiles [depending upon number of players] and puts them on his/her rack.

The double tiles [coloured triangle the same each end] are numbered 1 - 7 and the player with the lowest numbered double starts the game by placing the tile to cover 2 of the 4 centre squares.

The next player [if wished] matches the end or side of one of his/her tiles and places the tile so that the triangles on the 2 tiles make a coloured square. If the player cannot or chooses not to play a tile the player misses a turn and picks up, if available, a tile from those faced down at the beginning of the game.

Players cannot form squares using triangles of different colours.

The game continues until one player succeeds in playing his last tile [or no player can play]

Matches consist of several games to decide overall winner.

boardgame.name: Pathfinder Adventure Path: Serpent's Skull Player's Guide PDF
Serpent's Skull Player's Guide
boardgame.description:
Publisher blurb:

This guide seeks to aid players preparing to take part in the Serpent’s Skull Adventure Path, to arm them with spoiler-free details and rules elements useful in the forthcoming challenges, and to help create backgrounds that easily mesh with the campaign.

Along with advice for players of every race and character class in the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game—including those in the newly released Advanced Player’s Guide—details on Sargava, the country in closest proximity to the campaign’s events, and of the Jenivere, the ship conveying the PCs to adventure, should help ground players in the circumstances and events of this new Adventure Path.

Those looking for even more details and options for exotic adventures should take a look at Pathfinder Player’s Companion: Sargava.
